Message.Issue: Provide an overridable implementation of Dispose(bool) on 'MediaFile' or mark the type as sealed. A call to Dispose(false) should only clean up native resources. A call to Dispose(true) should clean up both managed and native resources.
Modify 'MediaFile.Dispose()' so that it calls Dispose(true), then calls GC.SuppressFinalize on the current object instance ('this' or 'Me' in Visual Basic), and then returns.
Modify 'MediaFile.~MediaFile()' so that it calls Dispose(false) and then returns.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'MediaFile.mciGetErrorString(int, StringBuilder, int)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

To reduce security risk, marshal parameter 'errorText' as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, specify MarshalAs explicitly, and set BestFitMapping=false; for added security, also set ThrowOnUnmappableChar=true.
Because it is a P/Invoke method, 'MediaFile.mciSendString(string, StringBuilder, int, IntPtr)' should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

To reduce security risk, marshal parameter 'command' as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, specify MarshalAs explicitly, and set BestFitMapping=false; for added security, also set ThrowOnUnmappableChar=true.

To reduce security risk, marshal parameter 'buffer' as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, specify MarshalAs explicitly, and set BestFitMapping=false; for added security, also set ThrowOnUnmappableChar=true.
Declare the first parameter of 'MediaFile.CloseFileEventHandler' as an object named 'sender'.
Declare the second parameter of 'MediaFile.CloseFileEventHandler' as an EventArgs, or an instance of a type that extends EventArgs, named 'e'.
Declare the first parameter of 'MediaFile.MCIErrorEventHandler' as an object named 'sender'.
Declare the second parameter of 'MediaFile.MCIErrorEventHandler' as an EventArgs, or an instance of a type that extends EventArgs, named 'e'.
Declare the first parameter of 'MediaFile.OpenFileEventHandler' as an object named 'sender'.
Declare the second parameter of 'MediaFile.OpenFileEventHandler' as an EventArgs, or an instance of a type that extends EventArgs, named 'e'.
Declare the first parameter of 'MediaFile.PauseFileEventHandler' as an object named 'sender'.
Declare the second parameter of 'MediaFile.PauseFileEventHandler' as an EventArgs, or an instance of a type that extends EventArgs, named 'e'.
Declare the first parameter of 'MediaFile.PlayFileEventHandler' as an object named 'sender'.
Declare the second parameter of 'MediaFile.PlayFileEventHandler' as an EventArgs, or an instance of a type that extends EventArgs, named 'e'.
Declare the first parameter of 'MediaFile.StopFileEventHandler' as an object named 'sender'.
Declare the second parameter of 'MediaFile.StopFileEventHandler' as an EventArgs, or an instance of a type that extends EventArgs, named 'e'.
Add [Serializable] to 'MediaPlayerException' as this type implements ISerializable.

Rule.Name: Declare event handlers correctly
Rule.Description: By convention, .NET events have two parameters that specify the event sender and event data. Event handler signatures should follow this form: void MyEventHandler(object sender, EventArgs e). The 'sender' parameter is always of type System.Object, even if it is possible to employ a more specific type. The 'e' parameter is always of type System.EventArgs. Events that do not provide event data should use the System.EventHandler delegate type. Event handlers return void so that they can send each event to multiple target methods. Any value returned by a target would be lost after the first call.
Rule.Resolution: Declare the first parameter of {0} as an object named 'sender'.
Declare the second parameter of {0} as an EventArgs, or an instance of a type that extends EventArgs, named 'e'.

Rule.Name: Implement IDisposable correctly
Rule.Description: All IDisposable types should implement the Dispose pattern correctly.
Rule.Resolution: Modify {0} so that it calls Dispose(true), then calls GC.SuppressFinalize on the current object instance ('this' or 'Me' in Visual Basic), and then returns.
Modify {0} so that it calls Dispose(false) and then returns.

Provide an overridable implementation of Dispose(bool) on {0} or mark the type as sealed. A call to Dispose(false) should only clean up native resources. A call to Dispose(true) should clean up both managed and native resources.

Rule.Name: Mark ISerializable types with SerializableAttribute
Rule.Description: The System.Runtime.Serialization.ISerializable interface allows the type to customize its serialization, while the Serializable attribute enables the runtime to recognize the type as being serializable.
Rule.Resolution: Add [Serializable] to {0} as this type implements ISerializable.

Rule.Name: Move P/Invokes to NativeMethods class
Rule.Description: This type contains members with the DllImport attribute. Members with the DllImport attribute should be contained in classes named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.
Rule.Resolution: Because it is a P/Invoke method, {0} should be defined in a class named NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods.

Rule.Name: Specify marshaling for P/Invoke string arguments
Rule.Description: When marshaling strings as ANSI (or as Auto on Win9x), some characters may be changed. If best-fit mapping is on, strings that appear different in Unicode will be marshaled to identical ANSI strings, which may lead to incorrect security decisions. Turning best-fit mapping off reduces this risk, as all characters without equivalents are mapped to '?'. Also, note that CharSet.Ansi is the default setting for all string marshaling; Unicode marshaling must be specified explicitly, either as a CharSet setting of DllImport or StructLayout, or as a MarshalAs attribute with a Unicode (or system-dependent) UnmanagedType.
Rule.Resolution: To reduce security risk, marshal parameter {0} as Unicode, by setting DllImport.CharSet to CharSet.Unicode, or by explicitly marshaling the parameter as UnmanagedType.LPWStr. If you need to marshal this string as ANSI or system-dependent, specify MarshalAs explicitly, and set BestFitMapping=false; for added security, also set ThrowOnUnmappableChar=true.
